page.title: 01Background information
page.content: The Rishton-Clayton area lies between 400m and 750m above sea level and is part of a broad valley running NE-SW. The area is drained by a number of small streams flowing over glacial deposits before joining the River Calder. The underlying rocks are all carboniferous in age consisting mainly of course sandstones, shales and coal. Coal was mined at several locations in the area though all mines are now closed. The sandstones have been widely used for building and the shales have been used for brickmaking. The main type of farming is dairying. The traditional cotton textile industry has disappeared from the area. Most people now travel to surrounding towns to work, especially Blackburn and Accrington.
